column2: In this way the fetter that consists in false view becomes an obscuration in the clear comprehension of cessation.The fetter of clinging is an obscuration in the clear comprehension of the truth of the path. Therein, the fetter of clinging refers to both the clinging to false view and the clinging to morality and vows. Clinging to false view therein refers to that notion in regard to false view and the five aggregates that have been appropriated and which are the basis of false view, as being preeminent and so on. Clinging to morality and vows refers to that notion on the part of one who perceives either morality, vows, both of these or the five aggregates that have been appropriated and which are the basis of that notion, as being equivalent to purity, liberation or definitive liberation. Furthermore, the clear comprehension of the path is in accordance with aspects, such as definitive liberation. Just how can the fetter of clinging be an obscuration in the clear comprehension of the path? Hence he says because one clings to the highest purity with the wrong motive i.e. because one clings to purity as either a just morality and vows, b an abode of pleasure pertinent to sensedesire, c ascetic practices or d the knowledge of enumerations etc.By clinging to a false view on account of just which one believes in purity, one clings to that same view as being preeminent.

In this context, the view that the connection between a word and its object belongs to the perfected is erroneous inversion. The view that objects exist by way of essential nature in exactly that way in which they appear is erroneous inversion. The view that incorporates the cause for the arising of the object is erroneous inversion, The views that incorporate imputation or negation in regard to the object are erroneous inversion. The view that the ownbeing of the object is in accord with its nominal designation is erroneous inversion. The views that regard the individual or universal characteristics of entities as substantially existent are erroneous inversion.The view that the purity or the lack of purity of actions is due to auspicious or inauspicious behaviour is erroneous inversion.

column1: yan na rūpādīn rūpādiṣv eva nityatvenānityatvena cānugacchati /
column2: that which does not understand form etc. just in relation to entities of form etc. or as permanent or impermanent.

column1: rūpādīnām ityādiśabdena vedanāsaṃjñāsaṃskāravijñānaskandhānāṃ pṛthivyaptejovāyvākāśadhātūnāṃ cakṣuḥśrotraghrāṇajihvākāyamanaāyatanānāṃ ca grahaṇaṃ / ātmeti śabdena pudgalasamāropānta iti skandhadhātvāyatana vyatiriktam avyatiriktaṃ vā vandhyāputravad asantam ātmānaṃ dravyataḥ paśyataḥ pudgalasyātmano vasturūpasamāropaṇam antaḥ /
column2: The word etc. in the term form etc. refers to the four other aggregates of sensation, ideation, the formative forces and consciousness, the elements of earth, water, fire, wind and space and the sensefields of sight, hearing, smell, taste, tactility and mind.The view which regards the self, which is nonexistent in actuality like the son of an infertile woman, as separate or not separate from the aggregates, elements or sensefields is an extreme because it imputes the self, in the nature of an entity, upon the personal entity.

column1: nairātmyam ityapavādāntaḥ /
column2: For, negation is described as imagining that something existent is nonexistent.

column1: ātmanastv asattvāt kathaṃ nairātmyam ity apavādānta āpadyata ityata āha prajñaptisato'pyapavādāt nairātmyam apavādānta iti sambadhyate /
column2: But if the self does not exist, how can its description as insubstantial be an extreme of negation? For, there is the negation of just that which exists as a designation. It is an extreme which negates the existence as something insubstantial that is referred to.

column1: sa punar dharmāṇāṃ santāno yasmin hetuphalasambandhaḥ prajñāyate /
column2: Moreover, it is a continuum of dharmas wherein the close connection of cause and result is evident.

column1: samudayo vā yatra devamanuṣyaprajñaptiḥ /
column2: Alternatively, it is a totality in regard to which the designation as god or human is made.

column1: tat parivarjanārthaṃ madhyamā pratipad ityātmanaḥ sadasattādarśanaparivarjanārthaṃ / tasyāḥ punar yasyā madhyamāyāḥ pratipado nirūpaṇārtham āha yadātmanairātmyayor madhyamam iti / kiṃ punas tan madhyaṃ /
column2: The middle way is for the purpose of avoiding both of these, i.e. for the purpose of avoiding the views that the self exists or does not exist and now, in order to define what is the middle way, he says i.e. that which holds the mean position between the existence of a self and its insubstantiality but what does that mean consist in?

column1: nirvikalpaṃ jñānaṃ / grāhyārthavikalpasyāntatvaṃ darśayitvā grāhakārthavikalpasyāntatvapradarśanārtham āha bhūtaṃ cittam ityādi /
column2: Direct intuition devoid of conceptual differentiation.Having shown that conceptual differentiation in regard to the apprehended object is an extreme and in order to demonstrate that conceptual differentiation in regard to the apprehending subject is also an extreme, he says the notion that mind is real etc.

column1: athavā pudgalasya samāropāpavādāntatvaṃ darśayitvā dharmasya samāropāpavādāntadarśanārtham āha bhūtaṃ cittam ityādi /
column2: Alternatively, after showing that imputation and negation in regard to the personal entity is an extreme and in order to show the extremes of imputation and negation in regard to the dharmas, he says the notion that mind is real etc.

column1: yathā pratibhāsate yathā vā'bhilapyate cittaṃ tathaiva bhūtaṃ vidyata iti /ayaṃ dharmasamāropāntaḥ abhūtasya cittasvabhāvabhūtatvena samāropāt /
column2: The notion that mind exists as a reality in exactly that way in which it appears, or, as it is expressed. This is the extreme of imputation in regard to the dharmas, because the ownbeing of mind which is without reality, is imputed as real.

column1: abhūtaṃ cittam ityapavādāntaḥ /
column2: The notion that mind is not real is the extreme of negation.

column1: tasya hi grāhyagrāhakarahitātmanā nirabhilāpyena ca vidyamānam apyabhūtam iti paśyataḥ sarvātmanā dharmasvabhāvāpavādād apavādāntaḥ / tat parivarjanārtham iti samāropāpavādarahitasya dharmanairātmyasya pravitedhārthaṃ madhyamā pratipad / sā yatra nacittaṃ na cetanā na mano na vijñānam iti /
column2: The view which regards mind as unreal although existent in a nature devoid of the apprehended object and apprehending subject and inexpressible is an extreme of negation because it completely negates the ownbeing of the dharmas.For the purpose of avoiding both of these, i.e. for the purpose of penetrating the insubstantiality of the dharmas which is devoid of imputation and negation, there is the middle way, i.e. Alternatively, that sphere within which mind does not arise in its nature as a collection of latent impressions accompanied by impurity, nor does volition characterized by formative influence, nor does thought in the aspect of selfconceit , nor does consciousness as conceptual differentiation this is described as the middle way.

column1: tatra cittam ālayavijñānaṃ sarvasrāvadharmavāsanābhiścittatvāt /
column2: Therein, mind refers to the storeconsciousness since it is the collection of latent impressions of all dharmas accompanied by impurity.

column1: cetanā manaskarma kuśalākuśalāvyākṛteṣu cittapreraṇakarmikā /
column2: Volition refers to the actions of mind and consists in the actions that stimulate mind toward the wholesome, the unwholesome and the neutral.

column1: manaḥ kliṣṭaṃ manaḥ /
column2: Thought refers to defiled mind.

column1: vijñānaṃ ṣaḍvijñānakāyāḥ /
column2: Consciousness refers to the six groups of consciousness.

column1: akuśalādayo dharmāḥ saṃkleśa iti vipakṣāntaḥ / kuśalādayo vyavadānam iti pratipakṣāntaḥ /
column2: The notion that the dharmas, such as those that are unwholesome, are defilement is an extreme in regard to adverse elements the notion that the wholesome ones etc.Are equivalent to purification is an extreme in regard to the counteragent.

column1: ādiśabdena sāvadyaanavadyalaukikalokottarasāsravānāsravasaṃskṛtāsaṃskṛtādayo nirdeśāḥ sambadhyante /
column2: By the word etc., the explanations of dharmas are referred to that are reprehensible, not reprehensible, mundane, supramundane, with and without impurity, conditioned and unconditioned etc.

column1: tatra yathaivākuśalāḥ kuśalāś ca dharmāḥ pratibhāsante'bhilapyante ca tathaiva saṃkleśo vyavadānañceti darśanaṃ vipakṣāntaḥ pratipakṣāntaś ca /
column2: In this respect, the extreme in regard to adverse elements and the extreme in regard to the counteragent refers to the notion that defilement and purification are exactly equivalent to the mode in which the unwholesome and wholesome dharmas appear and are articulated.

column1: tatrā'kuśalā akṣemārthatvāt / sāvadyā duścaritasamutthāpakatvāt / laukikā viparyastatvāt / sāsravā āsravānuśayitatvāt / saṃskṛtāḥ pratyayotpāditvāt /
column2: Therein the dharmas are unwholesome because they have the sense of discomfort they are reprehensible because they cause the manifestation of bad conduct they are mundane because they are erroneously inverted they are accompanied by impurity because they have a propensity towards impurity they are conditioned because they are produced from causal conditions.

column1: tad viparītās tu kuśalādayo veditavyāḥ /
column2: However, the wholesome ones etc. should be known as the inverse of these.

column1: tat parivarjanārthaṃ madhyamā pratipad iti / vipakṣapratipakṣayors tacchavdenābhisambandhaḥ / na madhyamā'tra pratipaj jñāyata ityata āha yo'syāntadvayasyā'nupagamo'nudāhāro'pravyāhāra iti /
column2: The middle way is for the purpose of avoiding both of these the term both of these refers to the adverse element and the counteragent.Since the middle way is not known in relation to this, he says that which consists in the nonacceptance, nonutterance and noncommunication of these two extremes.

column1: tatrā'nupagamo vipakṣapratipakṣayor anabhiniveśaḥ /
column2: Of these, nonacceptance refers to the absence of the notional attachment to adverse elements and the counteragent.

column1: anudāhāras tasmin vipakṣapratipakṣānte pareṣām asamādāpanāt / apravyāhāro vipakṣapratipakṣāntayor asaṃvarṇanāt /
column2: It is nonutterance because it does not cause others to accept these extremes in regard to adverse elements and the counteragent. It is noncommunication because it does not recommend to others the extremes in regard to adverse elements and the counteragent.

column1: tīrthikaśrāvakāntapratipakṣeṇa madhyamāṃ pratipadaṃ deśayitvā bodhisattvāntapratipakṣeṇa madhyamāṃ pratipadaṃ pratipādayann āha astīti śāśvatāntaḥ nāstītyucchedāntaḥ tayor eva pudgaladharmayoḥ /
column2: Having taught the middle way, he says the notion that both the personal entity and the dharmas exist is the extreme of eternalism the notion that they do not exist is the extreme of annihilationism.

column1: sarvadā svalakṣaṇasamārupād astīti śāśvatāntaḥ / sarvathā svarūpāpavādān nāstītyucchedāntaḥ / tat parivarjanārthaṃ madhyamā pratipad yad anayor antayor madhyamiti/
column2: The notion that they exist at all times is the extreme of eternalism because of the imputation of the individual characteristic the notion that they do not exist is the extreme of annihilationism because their essential nature is negated, in every respect.The middle way is for the purpose of avoiding both of these since it holds a mean position between the two extremes.

column1: ubhayāntavigamo'tra madhyamabhipretamityeke /
column2: Some believe that the mean in this context is intended as being separate from both extremes.

column1: ubhaya lakṣanamatra dvayorantayo madhyamityapare /
column2: Others maintain that the mean here lies between these two extremes and has the characteristic of both.

column1: kathaṃ kṛtvā ? yo'hyabhūtaparikalpavad dharmadhātuvadvā jñeyamn abhidheyaṃ ca vastu dravyataḥ paramārthataścāstītyabhiniveśaḥ sa śāśvatāntaḥ / tasya tahā'sattvāt /
column2: Having considered how should it be understood? The extreme of eternalism refers to the notional attachment to the view that an entity that is an object both of knowledge and verbal description, like the imagination of what is unreal or the dharmadhātu, exists substantially and in an ultimate sense because these do not exist as such.

column1: tadvā śaśaviṣāṇavan nāstyeveti darśanam ucchedāntaḥ /
column2: Similarly, the view that definitely does not exist, like the horns of a hare, is the extreme of annihilationism.

column1: kiṃ kāraṇaṃ ? tasya prajñaptito'stitvāt /
column2: What is the reason? Because it does exist as a designation.

column1: atas tan nirākaraṇenocchedānta ucyate / ataścāstitva nāstitvayor madhyaṃ dravyaḥ paramārthaś ca nasti prajñaptito'stītyubhayalakṣaṇaṃ bhavati /
column2: Hence, since it denies the existence of the latter, it is described as the extreme of annihilationism.Consequently, that which holds the mean position between existence and nonexistence has the characteristic of both since it does not exist substantially nor in an ultimate sense and does exist as a designation.

column1: vipakṣapratipakṣayoḥ samāropāntam adhikṛtyāha avidyā grāhyā grāhakā cetyantaḥ / evaṃ vidyā saṃskārā asaṃskṛtañca tat pratipakṣo grāhyaṃ grāhyakañcetyantaḥ /
column2: With reference to the extreme of imputation in regard to the adverse elements and their counteragent, he says the notion that nescience consists in the apprehended object and apprehending subject is one extreme likewise the notion that knowledge, the formative forces and the unconditioned, which is the counteragent to the latter, consists in the apprehended object and apprehending subject, is another extreme.

column1: atra ca yāvaj jarāmaraṇam iti paryantagrahāṇād vijñānanāmarūpādayo'dhyākṣipyante /
column2: Moreover, because of the reference here to the final member of the twelve nidäna by the words up until oldage and death, consciousness and name/form etc. are also included.

column1: tatrā'vidyā satyaratnāsaṃprakyānātmikā /
column2: Therein, nescience consists in an absence of the knowledge of the truths and the jewels.

column1: punyā punyānijñjasvabhāva cetanā sa punarbhāvabhisaṃskaraṇāt saṃskārāḥ / evaṃ saṃkleśalakṣaṇavyākhyānānusāreṇa vijñānādayo'pi vistareṇa vaktavyāḥ / vidyā'nāsravaṃ jñānaṃ / saṃskārāṇāṃ jñānamevā'saṃskṛtaṃ pratipakṣaḥ / atha vā'nyasmād asaṃskṛtād vyavacchedārtham āha tat pratipakṣa iti /
column2: The formative forces are impure volitions which have meritorious, demeritorious and neutral tendencies for their ownbeing because they are the formative influences for the new existence.Similarly, consciousness etc. should be stated in detail in a way that conforms with the explanations given in the section entitled The Characteristic of Defilement. Knowledge refers to direct intuition devoid of impurity. The counteragent to the formative forces refers just to direct intuition that is unconditioned it is only hence and in order to distinguish it from other unconditioned elements that he says the counteragent to the latter. However, others consider that in this respect the unconditioned is also eightfold because of the fact that it possesses nonorigination but the counteragent refers to volition that is without impurity because it does not formatively influence the new existence. Alternatively, the notion that the cessation of these consists in the apprehended object and apprehending subject is an extreme. By the word these, the nidänal beginning with consciousness and concluding with oldage and death, are referred to. Since it is not known whether sensation is an entity or a cause, he says it, i. e. name/form, is checked by that. By what is name/form checked? By the path which is without impurity and which is the counteragent to name/form.Knowledge and nescience which are nondual do not make a duality, thus, in this context the path is comprised only by direct intuition together with its associated elements.

column1: kena punas tan nāmarūpaṃ nirudhyate / nāmarūpapratipakṣeṇā'nāsraveṇa mārgeṇa /
column2: Consequently, since name/form is checked by this, there is cessation but what is the extreme here? Just the notional attachment to the apprehended object and apprehending subject.

column1: kiṃ kāraṇaṃ ? advayaprakṛtiṣv avidyādiṣv avidyamānadvayādhyāropapravṛttavāt /
column2: What is the reason? Because the imposition of a nonexisting duality occurs in regard to nescience etc. which are nondual by nature.

column1: evaṃ grāhyagrāhakānto dvidhā kṛṣṇaśuklapakṣabhedeneti /
column2: Thus, the extremes in regard to the apprehended object and apprehending subject are twofold according to their differentiation as belonging to the black or the white side.

column1: tatra kṛṣṇapakṣe dvādaśabhavāngāni avidyā yāvaj jarāmaraṇaṃ / evaṃ śuklapakṣe'pyvidhyādinirodhabhedena dvādaśaprakāra evāvidhyānirodho yāvaj jarāmaraṇanirodha iti /
column2: There in, the black side refers to the twelve limbs that consist in becoming, i.e. from nescience up until oldage and death. From the cessation of ignorance up until the cessation of oldage and death.

column1: atra ca nirydhyante'enā'vidyādaya iti tat pratipakṣabhūto mārga eva nirodhaśabdenoktaḥ /
column2: Moreover, in this context, it is just the path that is the counteragent to these that is signified by the word cessation since ignorance etc.Is checked on account of it.

column1: tat parivarjanārtham iti grāhyagrāhakāntaparivarjanārthaṃ madhyamāpratipad uktyabhisambadhyate /
column2: For the purpose of avoiding these, i.e. for the purpose of avoiding the extremes that consist in the apprehended object and apprehending subject, the middle way is mentioned, i.e. is referred to.

column1: sā ca na vijñāyata ityata āha vidyā cā'vidyā cādvayam etad iti /
column2: And since the latter is not known, he says both knowledge and nescience are nondual.

column1: kathaṃ vidyā cāvidyā ca yāvaj jarāmaraṇaṃ tan nirodhaścā'dvayam ityata āha vidyāvidyādīnāṃ grāhyagrāhakatvābhāvād iti /
column2: How can knowledge and nescience, up until oldage and death and the cessation of the latter, be nondual? Hence he says because of the absence of the apprehended object and apprehending subject on the part of knowledge and nescience etc.

column1: tad abhāvastv avidyādīnām advayaprakṛtitvāt /
column2: However, that absence is because of the fact that nescience etc. is nondual by nature.

column1: athavā vidyā'vidyeti parikalpitasvabhāvo'taś ca parikalpitasvabhāvayor vidyā'vidyayorabhāvasamatayā vidyā cā'vidyā cādvayam iti /
column2: Alternatively, since both knowledge and nescience have an imaginary nature, knowledge and nescience are nondual since the nonexistence of both knowledge and nescience, which have an imaginary nature, is the same.

column1: evaṃ saṃskārāṇām asaṃskṛtasya ca vijñānasya tan nirodhasya ca yāvaj jarāmaraṇasya tannirodhasya ceti vaktavyaḥ / kā punar atra madhyamā pratipat /
column2: It should be stated similarly for the formative forces, the unconditioned, consciousness and the cessation of the latter, up until oldage and death and its cessation.But what is the middle way in this context?

column1: etad eva jñānaṃ vidyā cāvidyā cādvayam etadavaidhīkāram iti na vidyotpādayitavyā nā'vidyā nirodhayitavyā / na saṃskārādayaḥ praheyāḥ /
column2: Just this knowledge that, since knowledge and nescience are nondual and do not make a duality, the knowledge to be generated is nonexistent and the nescience to be checked is nonexistent, the formative forces to be relinquished are nonexistent and the cessation of the latter which is to be attained is nonexistent.

column1: na tannirodhaḥ prāptavya iti yadevaṃ jñānam etadavaidhīkāraṃ // trividhaḥ sankleśa iti /
column2: The knowledge that this is so is the nonmaking of duality. Defilement is threefold.

column1: tatra kleśaḥ karmajanmasaṃkleśanimittatvāt svayañca kliṣṭatvāt svaparātmanor vyābādhahetutvād vā saṃkleśa ucyate /
column2: In this respect, moral defilements are described as defilements either because they cause the defilements of action and rebirth and they are defiled in themselves alternatively, it is because they cause disturbance to oneself and others.

column1: karmāpi kleśādhipatyanirvṛttatvāj janmahetutvāt svayam api ca kasyacit kliṣṭatvāt saṃkleśa ucyate /
column2: Action is also described as defilement, because it develops under the influence of moral defilement, it is the cause of rebirth and certain actions are morally defiled in themselves.

column1: janmāpi karmakleśanimittatvāt sarvopadravāspadabhūtatvāc ca saṃkleśaḥ / punaḥ kleśasankleśasya tridhā bhedapradarśanārtham āha kleśasankleśastrividha iti vistaraḥ /
column2: Rebirth too is described as defilement because it is both the cause of the moral defilement of action and it is the basis of all misfortune.Furthermore, in order to demonstrate the threefold differentiation of the defilement of moral defilements, he says the defilement of moral defilement is threefold etc.

column1: rāgadveṣamohā eva nimittaṃ śokādihetutvāt punar bhavahetutvāc ca /
column2: ii Passion, aversion and delusion indeed are causes because they are causes of grief etc. and the new existence.

column1: anye tvāhuḥ rāgādīnāṃ nimittaṃ tad anukūlā indriyārthāḥ ayoniśo manaskāraḥ rāgādivāsanā ālayavijñānasanniviṣṭā / evantu varṇayanti rāgādinimittaṃ tadābhāsa iti /
column2: However, others say that the causes of passion etc. are the sense faculties and objects conducive to it, superficial mental attention and the latent impressions of passion etc. that are lodged in the storeconsciousness but they claim that they, as they appear as these , are the cause of passion etc.

column1: punar bhavapraṇidhānaṃ punar bhavaprārthanā /
column2: iii The resolve for a new existence i. e. the desire for a new existence.

column1: yasya pratipakṣo jñānaśūnyateti vistaraḥ / tatra dṛṣṭānāṃ jñānaśūnyatā pratipakṣaḥ /
column2: The counteragents to these are i emptiness knowledge etc. Of these, the counteragent to false views is emptiness knowledge in this context, emptiness knowledge refers to knowledge that has emptiness for its object.

column1: śūnyatāviṣayaṃ jñānamātra jñānaśūnyatā / rāgādinimittapratipakṣo jñānā'nimittaṃ sarvanimittavigamāt /
column2: The counteragent to the cause of passion etc. is ii signless knowledge because it is devoid of all signs.Alternatively, signless knowledge refers to knowledge that has the signless for its object because it has the emptiness of imaginary passion etc. for its object.

column1: animittaviṣayaṃ vā jñānam jñānānimittaṃ /
column2: The counteragent to the resolve for the new existence is nonresolve knowledge.

column1: punarbhavapraṇidhānavigataṃ punarbhavaśūnyatāviṣayaṃ vā jñānaṃ jñānapraṇihitaṃ /
column2: Nonresolve knowledge refers to knowledge that is either devoid of the resolve for the new existence, or else, which has the emptiness of the new existence for its object.

column1: karmasankleśaḥ śubhāśubhakarmābhisaṃskāraḥ punarbhavākṣepakayoḥ śubhāśubhayoḥ karmaṇor upacayo'bhinirvṛttir abhisaṃskāraḥ /
column2: The defilement of action refers to the formative influence of virtuous and nonvirtuous actions. Formative influence refers to the accumulation and actualization of the actions, both virtuous and nonvirtuous, which project the new existence.

column1: yasya pratipakṣo jñānā'nabhisaṃskāraḥ /
column2: The counteragent to these is knowledge without formative influence.

column1: yena jñānena karma punarbhavann asya nā'bhisaṃskaroti taj jñānaṃ jñānābhisaṃskāraḥ /
column2: Knowledge without formative influence refers to that knowledge, on account of which, ones actions do not formatively influence the new existence and this has thusness for its object.

column1: jātasya cittacaittānāṃ pratikṣaṇotpādaḥ pratisandhibandhād ūrdhvam āmaraṇāt / punarbhavaprabandha iti kleśasahito maraṇabhavaḥ / tasmād anantaram antarbhāvaḥ / tataś ca punarpyupapattibhavaḥ / ārūpyasamāpattilābhinantu maraṇabhavād evānantaram upapattibhāvaḥ /
column2: The defilement of rebirth refers to the birth in a new existence, i.e. the mind at conception the arising of the mind and the mental concomitants every moment in one who has been born, i.e. subsequent to conception, up until death and the continuance of the new existence, i.e. the death state in accompaniment with moral defilement which is followed immediately by the intermediate state and following from the latter comes the rebirth state.However, for those who have gained the formless attainments, the rebirth state follows immediately after the death state.

column1: yasya pratipakṣo jñānā'jātir jñānānutpādo jñānāsvabhāvatā ca /
column2: The counteragents to these are nonbirth knowledge, nonproduction knowledge and the absence of ownbeing knowledge.

column1: tatrājātāḥ sarvadharmāḥ prikalpitātmktveneti yaj jñanaṃ śunyatāviṣayaṃ vā taj jñānajātiḥ /
column2: Of these, the nonbirth knowledge refers to the knowledge that all dharmas are unborn since they have the nature of imaginative construction alternatively, it is that which has emptiness for its object.

column1: vandhyāputravad asattvād asvabhāvo bhāvaprabandha iti yaj jñānaṃ taj jñānāsvabhāvatā /
column2: The absence of ownbeing knowledge refers to the knowledge that the continued existence of an entity is devoid of ownbeing, because, like the son of an infertile woman, it does not exist.

column1: etaj jñānaśūnyatādikaṃ saptavidhajñānaṃ yathoktasya saptavidhasya dṛṣṭyādivipakṣasya pratipakṣaḥ /
column2: These seven kinds of knowledge beginning with emptiness knowledge are the counteragents to the seven kinds of adverse elements beginning with false view as have just been described.

Because they are emptiness etc. by their very nature. What is meant is they are devoid of the ownbeing of false view etc. by their very nature. Hence, since the dharmas that are the object of emptiness knowledge etc. are emptiness etc. by their very nature, they are not caused to be empty etc. through emptiness knowledge etc. Thus, the object of signless knowledge which is devoid of the sign of passion etc. is not caused to be signless through signless knowledge because the emptiness of the sign of passion etc.Is, in itself, signless.

column2: The summary meaning of the absence of erroneous inversion a the bodhisattva penetrates the sign of tranquillity and the sign of direct intuition through the absence of erroneous inversion in relation to syllables. b He penetrates the sign of erroneous inversion through the absence of erroneous inversion in relation to objects. c He avoids the underlying cause of erroneous inversion through the absence of erroneous inversion in relation to mental activity.

column2: e He cultivates the path devoid of conceptual differentiation which acts as the counteragent to the latter through the absence of erroneous inversion in relation to the individual characteristic. f He penetrates that which is pure by nature through the absence of erroneous inversion in relation to the universal characteristic.He understands in full the relinquishment and nonrelinquishment of obscuration to the latter through the absence of erroneous inversion in relation to impure and pure mental activity.

column2: He penetrates that which is pure by nature, as being common to all dharmas, through the absence of erroneous inversion in relation to the universal characteristic.
